item.title: Israel's Red Sea Conundrum: Hit the Houthis or Iran
item.description: The Yemen-based rebels pose a lingering threat, and some security analysts argue that their patrons in Tehran should be in Israel’s crosshairs.

item.title: U.S. to Ease Aid Restrictions for Syria in Limited Show of Support for New Government
item.description: The move reflects Washington’s wariness about the U.S.-designated terror organization that leads the country.

item.title: Venezuelan Regime Hunts for Foreign Hostages to Pressure Its Rivals
item.description: Maduro has turned up the heat on the incoming Trump administration by recently seizing 50 foreigners, several of them American passport holders.

item.title: A Weakened Iran Prepares to Face Trump 2.0
item.description: Tehran is bracing for a tough confrontation with the incoming Trump administration while holding a weak hand after setbacks in 2024.

item.title: U.S. Plans $8 Billion Sale of Arms, Including Bombs, to Israel
item.description: The Biden administration notified Congress of a weapons package for Israel that is one of the largest new arms sales since the war in Gaza began.

item.title: Syria's New Islamic Government Creates Controversy With Education Overhaul
item.description: Documents released this week by the new government in Syria spur concerns about whether it will seek to impose a conservative Islamic worldview.

item.title: Italy, Caught Between U.S. and Iran, Seeks to Free Journalist
item.description: The case of Cecilia Sala, who is detained in Iran, is a test for Italy’s government as it gets caught up in Tehran’s shadow war with the U.S.

item.title: South Korea's Impeached President Fends Off Arrest Attempt Over Martial-Law Decree
item.description: Yoon Suk Yeol’s bodyguards thwarted investigators in another tense showdown resulting from his short-lived martial law decree.

item.title: China Adds to Sanctions of U.S. Defense Contractors Over Taiwan Arms Sales
item.description: Beijing sent a fresh warning to President-elect Donald Trump of the tools it can use to protect national interests.

item.title: What the End of a U.N. Agency Would Mean for Palestinians
item.description: Israeli legislation will effectively halt work by Unrwa, the U.N. organization that provides food, education and medical treatment in the Palestinian territories.

item.title: Palestinian Authority Bans Al Jazeera in West Bank
item.description: The ban comes as the PA battles militants from Hamas and its allies for control over parts of the West Bank, a fight that could shape the struggle for leadership of the Palestinian cause.

item.title: Jim Knaub, Premier Wheelchair Racer, Dies at 68
item.description: He motivated and challenged fellow paraplegics: ‘Why walk when you can fly?’

item.title: South Korean Police Raid Offices of Airline, Airport Involved in Plane Crash
item.description: The search warrant lists charges of professional negligence resulting in death, after 179 people were killed on a Jeju Air flight.

item.title: Fears Grow of Islamic State's Re-Emergence in Syria
item.description: The group is looking to exploit Syria’s uncertain future to rebuild its influence—half a decade after U.S.-led forces broke its hold on swaths of territory and millions of people.

item.title: How an FBI Sting Stopped a Russian Smuggler but Not His Hong Kong Supply Route
item.description: The case showed how difficult it is to stanch the flow of equipment to Russia through China, which the U.S. accuses of helping Moscow sustain the military production it needs to continue the war.

item.title: The Palestinian Authority Takes on Hamas Militants in West Bank Power Struggle
item.description: Weeks of deadly fighting have marked the most serious clashes between Palestinian factions in years.

item.title: U.S. Companies Vouched for China During Trump's First Term. Not Anymore.
item.description: American companies have largely gone silent about the importance of the U.S.-China relationship—they no longer see China as the land of opportunity.

item.title: Charges of Police Shakedown at Rave Lift Lid on Corruption in Indonesia
item.description: Action was taken to rein in rampant corruption two decades ago, but there are growing signs the world’s fourth-most populous country is losing the fight.

item.title: Damascus Uncorked: Syria Throws a New Year's Party for the Ages
item.description: People set aside divisions and anxiety about the future to mark a once-in-a-lifetime moment of renewal.

item.title: Russian Gas to Europe Stops Flowing After Ukraine Refuses to Renew Pipeline Deal
item.description: The move is expected to have limited impact on the continent, which has diversified its energy supplies since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
